instruction: What metric was chosen in the related study on discriminating functional ABS parasites at the single cell level and how far can this metric go?

instruction: How did the researchers use machine learning techniques in their study on discriminating functional ABS parasites at the single cell level?
Output: The researchers used machine learning techniques in their study by employing Support Vector Machine (SVM) analysis. They applied SVM to predict and discriminate the different stages of the asexual blood staged (ABS) parasites at the single cell level. The SVM analysis provided a 100% prediction accuracy for both schizonts and trophozoites, and achieved a 92% and 98% accuracy for predicting control and ring staged infected red blood cells (RBCs), respectively. This utilization of machine learning allowed for accurate identification and quantification of the ABS parasite stages, contributing to monitoring the progression and recovery from malaria.

instruction: Can visible microspectrophotometry coupled with machine learning be used to discriminate functional asexual blood staged (ABS) parasites at the single cell level in the study on monitoring the progression and recovery from malaria?
Output: Yes, visible microspectrophotometry coupled with machine learning can be used to discriminate functional asexual blood staged (ABS) parasites at the single cell level in the study on monitoring the progression and recovery from malaria. The study utilized Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Support Vector Machine Analysis to achieve excellent discrimination between different stages of ABS parasites, with high prediction accuracy for schizonts, trophozoites, control, and ring staged infected red blood cells (RBCs).
